column9: Description

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Lying on your back. 2) Pull your left knee in towards your chest and slightly over to your right shoulder. 3) Hold your left arm out to the side. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Come onto all fours on the floor. 2) Bring your left leg up under your chest with your knee bent so that your foot and lower leg is lying across the middle of your body. 3) Sit back over your leg and reach your arms forward (there should be a good stretch in your buttock). 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Lying on your back with your legs out straight. 2) Bend your left leg up and pull it over to the right leg with your right arm. 3) Keep your right arm on the floor out to your side. 4) Pull the leg across until you feel a stretch on the outside of your hip. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 6) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, knee pain
column9: To stretch your left side: 1) Standing tall, engage your core*, step your right leg in front of your left leg. 2) Shunt your hips to the left and bring your left arm over the top your head so you are making a banana shape with your body. 3) Feel a stretch up the side of your left hip, hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

1) Sit with your legs out straight. 2) Cross your right leg over your left so your right foot is over your left leg. 3) Pull your right knee into your chest until you feel a stretch up the side of the hip / buttock. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, knee pain
column9: 1) Kneel down on the ground and bring your right leg out to the side with your knee straight. 2) Drop your right hip to the floor until your feel a stretch up the inner thigh. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

column3: Back of thigh stretch (lying on back)
column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Lie on your back holding a towel or piece of strong resistance band. 2) Bend up your right knee and lift your leg placing the towel around your foot and holding onto each end with your hands. 3) Pull your right leg up in towards your chest until you feel a stretch up the back of your leg. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Kneel on the ground - place a pillow under your left knee if you have sensitive knees. 2) Straighten out your right leg in front of you. 3) Keep your lumbar curve (concavity) and lean forward from your pelvis (not lower back). 3) Feel a stretch up the back of the leg, hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Standing, straighten out your right leg with your heel on the ground. 2) Putting your weight on your left side bend your left knee and lean over your right leg until your feel a stretch up the back of your leg. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

1) Lying on your back. 2) Pull your right  knee in towards your chest and slightly over to your left shoulder with your left hand. 3) Hold onto your lower right leg with your right hand .4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Gently pull your lower right leg over to your left side and resist with your right hand for 3-5 seconds. 6) Relax and repeat 3 times. 4) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Runners, walkers, repetitive injuries ankle, balance difficulty
column9: 1) Standing tall, draw your shoulder blades down and engage your core*. 2) Bring your right foot up and place it either on the inside of your left calf or above your knee on the inside of your left thigh. 3) Make sure your right knee is out to the right. 4) Try to hold this position for 20 seconds or build up to this. 5) Repeat the other side. (*See related exercises)

column6: Runners, walkers, repetitive injuries ankle, balance difficulty
column9: 1) Standing tall, draw your shoulder blades down and engage your core*. 2) Bring your right knee up to your chest and pull it gently in. 3) With your right hand supporting your right leg, rotate your hip out to the right as far as comfortable, feeling a stretch in the hip joint (this should not be painful). 4) Try to hold this position for 20 seconds or build up to this. 5) Repeat the other side. (*See related exercises)

1) Standing tall, bend your right knee and reach behind with your right arm to hold your right foot. 2) Draw your shoulders down and find neutral spine* (do not tilt forward). 3) Gently pull your foot into your buttocks until you feel a stretch up the front of your right thigh. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

To stretch your right quad: 1) Kneel down on the ground placing a pillow under your right knee if required and lunge your left leg out in front so that your knee is at a right angle (hold onto a chair for support if needed). 2) Keep your back straight (neutral spine*) and do not twist to the side.3) Lunge forward on your back leg slightly and then tuck your tailbone under (curling your pubic bone up towards the ceiling) until you should feel a stretch up the front of your back leg (right), to increase the stretch you can hold onto your right foot. 4) Make sure your knee does not come over your ankle when you lunge forward. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

1) Lie on your right side with your head resting on your right arm and right knee bent for stability. 2) Bend your left knee and hold onto your left foot with your left hand. 3) Stabilise your pelvis (don't allow it to move forward) - all the movement should come from your leg. 4) Pull your left leg back until you feel a stretch up the front of the right thigh. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 6) Repeat twice each side.

column3: Front of hip stretch Swiss Ball (hip flexor)
column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1)Place a Swiss Ball next to a sturdy chair / table if needed. 2) Bring your left leg over the top of a Swiss Ball and your right leg behind you on the Swiss Ball (the Swiss Ball has to be small enough that both feet can contact the ground). 3) Hold onto the chair table, tilt your pelvis forward until you feel a stretch up the front of the right hip. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, hip instability, core weakness
column9: To strengthen your right side: 1) Tie a piece of resistance band to a sturdy table leg, and the other end to your right ankle. 2) Stand with your left side to the table leg and at a distance away to give appropriate resistance to the muscles of your outer hip / buttocks. 3) Draw your shoulders down and engage your core*. 4) Breathe in and as your breathe out, keeping your leg straight move it away from your body. 5) Breathe in and slowly return you leg back to the other leg. 6) Repeat 10-15 times. 7) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

To strengthen your left side: 1) Tie a piece of resistance band to a sturdy table leg, and the other end to your left ankle. 2) Stand with your left side to the table leg and at a distance away to give appropriate resistance to the muscles of your inner thigh and hip. 3) Draw your shoulders down and engage your core*. 4) Breathe in and as your breathe out, keeping your leg straight move it across your body to the right in front of your right leg. 5) Breathe in and slowly return you leg back. 6) Repeat 10-15 times. 7) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

To strengthen your right side: 1) Tie a piece of resistance band to a sturdy table leg, and the other end to your right ankle. 2) Stand with your right leg directly in front of the table leg and at a distance away to give appropriate resistance to the muscles at the back of your hip and thigh. 3) Draw your shoulders down and engage your core*. 4) Breathe in and as your breathe out, keeping your leg straight extend it out behind you. 5) Breathe in and slowly return you leg back. 6) Repeat 10-15 times. 7) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

1) Sit on the floor with knees apart and feet together. 2) Sit tall, drawing shoulder blades down and trying to keep your lumbar curve concave (don't round through your back). 3) Try to bring your feet in towards your groin to increase the stretch. 4) With your elbow resting on your knees gently push down to increase the stretch in your inner thighs and hold for 20 seconds. 5) Push your knees up into your elbows with equal resistance from your elbows for 3-5 seconds. 6) Repeat this 3 - 5 times.

column6: Runners, walkers, hip tightness, lower back pain
column9: 1) Lie on your back with your legs out straight. 2) Engage your core*, bend your right knee up and gently but firmly pull it into your chest. 3) Clasping your hands around your knee gently roll your hip out to the right and then down and over to the left in and anti-clockwise movement - repeat 5 times. 4) Then rotate your hip in a clockwise movement repeating 5 times. 5) Repeat for the other hip. (*See related exercises)

1) Sitting cross legged or legs out straight. 2) Place a spiky ball under your right buttock in a spot that feels tender/ tight. 3) Gently lower your buttock down over the spiky ball. 4) Use your body weight to control the amount of pressure the spiky ball exerts through your buttock. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and if too sore don't put as much weight through. 6) Repeat left side.

column3: Front of hip stretch standing (hip flexor)
column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Standing tall with feet hip width apart. 2) Step your left leg out in front. 3) Bend both your left and right knees and tilt your pubic bone / pelvis up to the ceiling. 4) Lunge forward slightly until you feel a stretch up the front of the right hip. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.

1) Kneel down on the ground placing a pillow under your right knee if required and lunge your left leg out in front so that your knee is at a right angle (hold onto a chair for support if needed). 2) Keep your back in neutral spine* and do not twist to the side.3) Lunge forward on your back leg, tucking your tailbone under (curling your pubic bone up towards the ceiling), you should feel a stretch up the front of your back leg (right). 4) Make sure your knee does not come over your ankle when you lunge forward. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 6) Straighten out your left leg and keeping your lumbar curve (neutral spine*) lean over your left leg until you feel a stretch up the back of your left leg. 7) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 8) Keeping your left leg as it is, rotate your torso to the left and lean over the leg feeling a stretch up the outside of the back of the leg - hold for 20-30 seconds. 9) Come back up, turn your body as it is, around to the right so that the inside of your left leg is facing the floor and push your inner thigh into the floor feeling a stretch in the inner thigh - hold for 20-30 seconds. 10) Repeat twice each side. (*See related exercises)

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, knee weakness
column9: 1) Standing tall with feet hip width apart. 2) Place the Swiss Ball behind you against a wall in the small of your lower back. 3) Draw your shoulders down, engage your core* and squat down as if you are going to sit down in a chair. 4) Your knees travel directly in line with your ankles. 5) Your arms can straighten out in front as you squat to help balance you.6) Repeat 10-15 times. (*See related exercises)

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, hip weakness
column9: 1) Standing tall with arms out front for balance and feet hip width or a little wider. 2) Try to concentrate on not leaning forward or back, weight should be through the mid to forefoot. 3) Squat down as far as you can, feet as flat as possible - you should feel no pain in hips, knees or ankles. 4) Repeat 10-15 times.

column2: Hip / leg extensions using a Swiss Ball
column3: Hip /leg strength using a Swiss Ball
column9: 1) Lie on your back with a Swiss Ball under your bent knees and your heels resting on the top of the Swiss Ball, arms by your side. 2) Take a breath in and as you breathe out come up into a shoulder bridge. 2) Breathe in and as you breathe out extend your legs out straightening them from this position. 3) Breathe in and return your legs back to the starting position. 4) Staying up in the bridge repeat 6-10 times.

1) Place a Swiss ball behind your lower back against a wall. 2) Step your right foot out in front of you maintaining pressure between your lower back and the Swiss Ball. 3) Draw your shoulders down and activate your core*. 4) Breathe in and as you breathe out lunge down keeping your knee in line with your ankle. 5) Straighten back up and repeat 10-15 times. 6) Repeat other side. (*See related exercises)

1) Lie on you back with you knees bent up and feet flat on the ground. 2) Find neutral spine* and activate you core*. 3) Draw your shoulder blades down the back of your ribcage. 3) Tighten your buttock muscles and lift your buttocks off the floor, still trying to maintain a contraction in the muscle, lower your buttocks back down. 4) Repeat 15 times and do 3 sets.  (*See related exercises)

column2: Single leg curl on Swiss Ball
column3: Single leg curl on a Swiss Ball
column9: 1) Lying on your back with your legs out straight and heels resting on a Swiss ball. 2) Slowly raise your hips up off the floor. 3) Lift your right leg off the swiss ball and lengthen your right leg to the ceiling and hold it there. 4) Push your left leg out straight pushing the swiss ball away and then bend it back in allowing the swiss ball to come back in towards you. 5) Repeat 6-8 times (less to start if need be). 6) Repeat other side.

column2: Single gluteal lift on Swiss Ball
column3: Single buttock lift on Swiss Ball
column9: 1) Lying on your back with your hips and knees flexed and heels contacting a Swiss ball. 2) Lift your right leg off the swiss ball, lengthening it towards the ceiling and hold it there. 4) Keeping your left heel in contact with the Swiss ball, lift your hips up and squeeze your buttock muscles and then lower back down. 5) Repeat 6-8 times (less to start if need be). 6) Repeat other side.

1) Stand with your feet hip width apart. 2) Take a step out with each foot a bit further and turn your toes out slightly. 3) Using your arms to help balance you straight out in front, squat down slowly all the way (only continue if there is no pain in your pelvis, hips or knees). 4) Keep your feet flat, relax your arms to a comfortable position (you can put your elbows at your inner thighs to gently push your legs further apart if this is comfortable). 5) Hold this position for up to 60 seconds only if pain free.

column3: Leg extension lying on a ball
column9: 1) Lying on a Swiss ball with your abdomen on the ball with hands directly under shoulders, head in line with spine, toes contacting floor. 2) Activate core and stabilise through pelvis, trying not to let your lower back dip. 3) Breathe in and as you breathe out raise one leg, return down as you breathe in. 4) Repeat other side. 5) Repeat 6-8 times each side

column2: Prone opposite arm and leg raise
column3: Opposite arm ad leg raise on a ball
column9: 1) Lying on a Swiss ball with your abdomen on the ball with hands directly under shoulders, head in line with spine, toes contacting floor. 2) Activate core and stabilise through pelvis. 3) Breathe in and as you breathe out raise one leg and opposite arm simultaneously without arching your lower back. 4) Breathe out as you return and repeat the other side. 5) Repeat 6-8 times both sides.

To strengthen your left side: 1) Lie on your right side with your hips and knees flexed so that your ankles are in line with your buttocks and all your joints are stacked (shoulder directly above shoulder and hip on hip - not rolling back or forth) 2) Rest your head in your right hand and rest your left arm where comfortable. 3) Activate your core, breathe in and as you breathe out lift your left knee but keeping your ankles contacting each other. 4) Breathe in as you lower your knee back down. 5) Breathe out and raise your knee again. 4) Repeat 8-10 times both sides.

column6: Lower back pain / stiffness, rib pain
column9: To stretch your left side: 1) Sit on the ground with your right leg out straight and your left leg bent in. 2) Twist your upper body so you are completely facing your bent left knee, hold onto the left knee with your right hand. 3) Reach your left arm up over your head towards your straight leg remembering to keep your body facing the bent knee. 4) You should feel a deep stretch in the left side of your lower back. 5) Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds and with every breath as you breathe out try to reach a little further and increase the stretch. 6) Repeat the above steps for the other side.

column3: Side and back torso stretch on ball
column9: 1) Start by sitting on a Swiss ball 2) Activate your core* and find neutral spine*, draw your shoulders down the back of your ribcage. 3) Reach your left arm over the top of your head and with your other hand hold onto your left wrist to increase the stretch by pulling over to the right. 4) You should feel the stretch up the side of your ribcage. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds then bring the arm across the front of the body pulling your wrist again and you will feel it further into your back - hold again for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.  (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

1) Start by sitting on a Swiss ball 2) Activate your core* and find neutral spine*, draw your shoulders down the back of your ribcage. 3) Reach your left arm over the top of your head and with your other hand hold onto your left wrist to increase the stretch by pulling over to the right. 4) At the same time using your hips on the ball push to the right - creating a banana like shape - you should feel the stretch in the side of you lower back. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.  (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

column3: Hamstring (back of thigh) stretch using foam roller
Leg circles lying on your back with bent knee

column2: One leg circles with straight legs - pilates
column3: Leg circles lying on your back with straight leg

column9: To stretch your right psoas (hip flexor): 1) Kneel down on the ground placing a pillow under your right knee if required and lunge your left leg out in front so that your knee is at a right angle (hold onto a chair for support if needed). 2) Keep your back in neutral spine (slight curve or concavity in your lower back) and keep your hips facing forward. 3) Lunge forward on your back leg, tucking your tailbone under (curling your pubic bone up towards the ceiling), you should feel a stretch up the front of your back leg (right). 4) Make sure your knee does not come over your ankle when you lunge forward. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.

To stretch the right piriformis: 1) Lie flat on your back with both knees bent up 2) Cross your right leg over your left leg so that your ankle is resting on your left thigh. 3) Reach your left arm around your left leg and your right arm through your right leg so that you interlace your hands around your left leg.  4) Pull your left leg up towards your chest until you feel a stretch in your right buttock and up the back of your thigh (try to keep your tailbone down on the floor - you will feel the stretch sooner than if you allow your tailbone to lift off the floor). 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.

To stretch the left piriformis: 1) Sit towards the edge of a stable chair with both feet flat on the ground and knees at 90 degrees. 2) Cross your left leg over the other leg so that your ankle is resting on your right thigh. 3) Keep your back in neutral spine (slight curve or concavity in your lower back) and bend forward from your pelvis (not your lower back). 4) You should feel a stretch through your left buttock and up the back of the thigh. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side.
